contentrichtext.text: {{nihongo|'''Hisai'''|久居市|Hisai-shi}} was a [[cities of Japan|city]] located in [[Mie Prefecture|Mie]], [[Japan]]. As of 2003, the city had an estimated [[population]] of 41,669 and the [[population density|density]] of 610.98 persons per km². The total area was 68.20 km². The city was founded on August 1, 1970. On January 1, 2006 Hisai, along with the towns of [[Anō, Mie|Anō]], [[Geinō, Mie|Geinō]] and [[Kawage, Mie|Kawage]], the village of [[Misato, Mie|Misato]], all from [[Age District, Mie|Age District]], the towns of [[Hakusan, Mie|Hakusan]], [[Ichishi, Mie|Ichishi]] and [[Karasu, Mie|Karasu]], and the village of [[Misugi, Mie|Misugi]], all from [[Ichishi District, Mie|Ichishi District]], was merged into the expanded city of [[Tsu, Mie|Tsu]] and no longer exists as an independent [[municipalities of Japan|municipality]]. Since 1999 Hisai City has been operating 4 wind turbines with a total capacity of 3 MW which amounts to about 16% of the city's power demand.[http://www.nef.or.jp/english/awards/1999/00syo11.htm] [http://www.enecho.meti.go.jp/english/energy/new_energy/wind_1.html] ==External links== * [http://www.info.city.tsu.mie.jp/ Official website of Tsu] {{ja icon}} {{Mie}} [[Category:Dissolved municipalities of Mie Prefecture]] {{Mie-geo-stub}}
